turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Harry Harry Harry Harry Harry, I told you to use fewer briquettes and now look what you've done. You've cremated them.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: That's what I do. Do you wanna do it??

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Look if you think you know how, why don't you pre-measure the briquettes in little packages, put out a product, support me for a while!

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Yes she is, but she's very upset, so she's not seeing anyone.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Oh, I'm Judy, I go to school with her, I wanted to tell her I'm sorry about Thomas J.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Well maybe she'll feel better in a couple of days.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Will you tell her I came by?

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: Mademoiselle Sultenfuss and the amazing Dr. J! How's the summer treating you?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: It's okay. Mr. Bixler, I finished all the books for summer reading.

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: Really? Already? The summer's just begun.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Yes, and now I'm reading War & Peace for fun.

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: No wonder you're my prize pupil. What about you Thomas J?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Mr. Bixler, how come you're painting this old house?

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: Well I just bought it, now I'm fixing it up.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: This is one big house for one single person.

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: Well, you never can tell...  I might get a pet.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: How are you gonna get the money for this old house if you're not working?

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: Well I'm gonna teach creative writing this summer, so, I'm doing some work.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: What do you get for that?

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: Me, two hours a week, talking about poetry. This an interrogation Vada?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: No. Well, guess i'll go home and finish off War & Peace.

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: It's summer! You're kids! Go play!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Uh huh, I wanna be a writer.

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: Vada, this is an adult writing class.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Loads of ice-cream by Vada Sultenfuss I like ice-cream a whole lot, It tastes good when days are hot, On a cone or in a dish, This would be my only wish, Vanilla, chocolate or rocky road, Even with pie a la mode.

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: Okay, okay we don't have to talk about him, Vada, Vada we don't have to talk about him, it's okay. We won't talk about him all right?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Justin and Ronda say that I should tell people what I feel.

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: Come here, sit down over here.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I love you like my Dad loves Shelly. I wanna live here.

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: Pause as he takes all this in I think your Dad would miss you.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: No he wouldn't, I can't go home.

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: That's Suzanne.  She and I are gonna be married this Fall.

turns.speaker: MR. BIXLER
turns.text: I...I was gonna bring her to class next week. I wanted to hear your poem. Oh Vada, please honey I cared for him too, Vada please! Vada, Vada sweetheart don't.....

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I can't stay, I just came to read my poem.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Weeping willow with your tears running down, Why do you always weep and frown, Is it because he left you one day, Is it because he could not stay, On your branches he would swing, Do you long for the happiness that they would bring, He found shelter in your shade, He thought his laughter would never fade, Weeping willow stop your tears, There is something to calm your fears, You think death as if you forever part, But I know he'll always be in your heart.

turns.speaker: NURSE RANDALL
turns.text: So you fill it with water like this, and what have you got? A water gun.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Cool, can I get one for Vada?

turns.speaker: NURSE RANDALL
turns.text: Why do you think she says that?

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Cause she gets scared of all those dead people in her house, and you know that saying, If you can't beat 'em, join 'em, well if she's one of them, she won't be as scared.

turns.speaker: NURSE RANDALL
turns.text: You know what I think? I think Vada's very lucky to have a friend like you.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: He must like Shelly, I never saw him hit anyone in his life.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Yes I do, and I think she's very good for your father.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: After your mother died, he was sad all the time, but before that, he was pretty funny.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Now when I see him with Shelly, sometimes he seems like the old Harry.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Well he wasn't one of the Marx brothers, but he made me laugh.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: You know Vada, you shouldn't let those girls upset you.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I'm not upset. I will never play with those girls. I only surround myself with people who I find intellectually stimulating.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Ooh, that's a pretty ring you're wearing.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: It's a mood ring, it tells what mood I'm in.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I don't think so.  Shelly, how can I get thirty five dollars?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I think you'd make a fine writer, did you ask your Dad?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: He won't give it to me.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Well you don't know that. Ask him.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: My ball, I lost my ball.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Can we look around in your camper?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Sure. I'll give you the royal tour.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Ohh, right. Would you like a soda?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Did you read ALL these books?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Daddy said it's bad when people get divorced.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Well, sometimes married people just find out they can't live with each other.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Bye. Well Miss Vada, what d'you say we head back?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Can I use your bathroom first?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: You don't have to wait, daddy'll be mad if you're late.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: So how come you're putting lipstick on?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: A girl's always gotta look her best.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I think lipstick looks fake, no-ones lips are that color.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Shelly, do you think I'm pretty?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Yes, Vada I think you're very pretty. You've got these great big sparkling eyes, the cutest little nose, an amazing mouth.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: The boys at school don't think I am.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: They'll come around. Close your eyes, I wanna bring out the gorgeous color in them. The first rule in applying eye makeup, is you can never wear enough blue eye shadow.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Do you like putting makeup on people?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Uh huh, i've been trying to get out to Hollywood for years to do makeup for all the stars, I haven't gotten there yet.  All right, open your eyes.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Ssshhhhh, I don't want them to see me.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Hey, I thought I recognized you two, hi Vada.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: This is Danny and Ralph, they own the Dino Raphael salon in Detroit.  We used to be married.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Are you here to take Shelly back?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I don't think that that roller coaster agreed with your bad stomach. You know Vada you have to watch what you eat here, I remember one time I went to a carnival with my cousins David and Frank, and they both ate hot dogs, and the next day they came down with nephritis.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Nephritis? It's a kidney disease, you don't get it from hot dogs.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Well, I'm no doctor. All I know is, the next day they had really high fevers, and their faces got very fat. They baffled medical science, they were in a magazine.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Vada? Would you like us to get you another goldfish?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: NO!, He's fine.  Fish are very resilient animals you know. Don't worry, I won't get another fish.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Well he just left, what's wrong?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: What do you mean you're hemorrhaging?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I don't want, I don't need your help....

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: It's okay, come on upstairs, we have to have a little talk.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: My Mommy and Daddy did THAT?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: It's actually a very beautiful thing, and look there wouldn't have been a Vada.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I think it should be outlawed.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Believe me, some day, you'll feel differently.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I'll pay it back, besides, I don't think i'll ever go to class again.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I'll tell you what, you dedicate your first book to me, and we'll forget about the whole thing.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Wow, this is the coolest thing, like you really eat and sleep here?

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: I'm gonna drive us to Liverpool.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Well, I guess you found my secret hiding place.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Nothing in particular, just putting it away for a rainy day.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Hey there's your Dad and Shelly.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: I can't, I have to go home.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Hey look at this, no feet!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Oh wow, a real evil canieval.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: That's Mr. Bixler, let's go talk to him.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: I don't wanna talk to a teacher, it's summer!

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Why? It's not dinner time yet.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Dinner time?? You're like a dog! You just go home to eat.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: It doesn't work, it always stays black.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: It's only black when you're around 'cause you put me in a bad mood.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: She's crazy, she wants to go to school over the summer.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: It's not a real school, it's a writing class, I wanna be a writer.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: She only wants to do it because her sweetie pie's the teacher.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Maybe they had a big breakfast.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: I'm gonna be an acrobat when I grow up.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Big deal, I can do that too.  Thomas J, you got something!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Reel it in.  He's only tiny, throw him back.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: I don't like touching fish, how do you pull the hook out without touching it?

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Yeah he got away. Come on let's go.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Hey, we can become blood brothers.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: You could pick that scab on your arm.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: If I do it, can we go?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: A girl can never wear enough eye shadow.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Oh, in the garage. Walk me over.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: That was Grammoo's. It's a phrenology chart, they used to study the bumps in your head to see if you had a good personality or not. Come here, i'll diagnose your head.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Hey, where does it say that?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: No. Grammoo said she's in heaven.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: What do you think it's like?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I think, everybody gets their own white horse, and all they do is ride and eat marshmallows all day, and everybody's best friends with everybody else, when you play sports, there's no teams, so nobody gets picked last.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: But, what if you're afraid to ride horses?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: It doesn't matter, 'cause they're not regular horses, they got wings, and it's no big deal if you fall, you just land in cloud.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: That doesn't sound so bad, come on, we'll never find that streamer.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: What do you want? My mom will skin me alive if she finds I'm out here.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Let's go to the church, they're playing bingo tonight.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: I told you i'll get in trouble.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: They're not gonna let us in Vada, we're kids.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: We're not gonna bet, we're just gonna watch.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Watch bingo? I don't even like to play bingo.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: You know I'm not allowed outside my myself after dark.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Hey Vada, guess what we got?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: HEY YOU!!!!  I'm gonna get you!!!  I'll get you!!!!

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Pointing There's a beehive right there!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Are you crazy, you'll get stung!!

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: You're right, let's knock it down.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: What do you want it for anyway?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: My mood ring! It fell off! I gotta find it!

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: But I have my clothes on!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: California, I'm going to Hollywood to live with the Brady Bunch.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: I wanna live with them too.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: No, you can't, they have enough kids, you'll have to live with the Partridge Family.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: I'm tired of running away. Besides, we past this place two times already. We're not getting nowhere.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: My Dad gave Shelly a ring.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Wow, was it a decoder ring?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: You're such a retard, it was an engagement ring.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: So now you'll have a mother.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: He likes her better than me.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: I'm hungry, I can't last any longer.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: I have to anyway, my mom will be worried.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Leave then, some friend you are.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: You can come to my house for dinner?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Oh, that's probably Thomas J, I don't wanna see him. It's not fair. Nothing happens to boys.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Hi Vada, can you come out?

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Please, it's real hot, maybe we can go swimming?

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Well when you get older, you just have to.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: You can't marry a teacher, it's against the law.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Yes it is, cause then he'll give you all A's and it won't be fair.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Maybe we should, just to see what's the big deal.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Here, practice on your arm like this.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: But then I won't be able to see anything.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Okay on the count of three.

turns.speaker: THOMAS J
turns.text: Well if you don't get to marry Mr. Bixler.

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: Well, then, I'll take it up with her.

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: ... trouser width, this is all classic.  Which means safe, something I'd wear.

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: You should look like you dressed yourself.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: And I'm supposed to respect your fashion tips, because you're what, a New Yorker?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Long trip.  Pretty nice of you to come.

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: Well, I'm close to her.  I wanted to meet the one that got away.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'm just glad someone finally put this thing in its proper perspective.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'll call George's parents. Tell them I need a best man who actually looks after me.

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: Part of being a New Yorker.

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: Is it ever embarrassing, having your bum kissed in public?

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: If your ass isn't chapped, you are not a good-writer of note.

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: Is it sad to be an editor, and bask only in reflected insincerity?

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: I've adjusted, and thanks for asking.

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: See the pull of a book like Twenty Chefs, is not who I put in.  It's who I leave out.

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: Which is everyone you couldn't get in.

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: Plus some guys whose food I don't like.

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: Is Newsday a real interview, or just some cute guy you're setting me up w...

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: ... I don't send you men, anymore. You don't know what to do with them.

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: Sometimes I do.  Like for two months.

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: No, no, the opposite.  That's my best friend, Michael O'Neal. He sounds desperate to talk.

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: Nine years, we've seen each other through everything.  Losing jobs, losing parents, losing lovers... travelled all over, we've had the best times.  The best times of my life, maybe.  Just drinking and talking.  Even over a phone.

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: No, he's nothing like me.  He's like you.  Only straight.

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: He's the salt of the earth.  Kind and loyal and generous.  The one constant thing in my life, is he'll always be there.

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: He's still in love with you.

turns.speaker: DIGGER
turns.text: Whenever George tells someone how steadfast I am, he always makes me sound boring.

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: Solid and genuine is not boring. Michael can be completely insane...

turns.speaker: JULIANNE
turns.text: He takes a razor from his dinky little dopp kit, cuts his fingertip, takes my hand, does the same to me...
